timeline.bodyText: I think reference is right word here; so we should update line 25. We already use the word "dependency" for the relationship between two Maven artifacts. Shall we use "reference" for the relationship from a class file to a symbol?
timeline.author: suztomo
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -24,7 +24,7 @@ permalink: /glossary
 - **Linkage error**: an abnormal condition of a classpath in which a
   "class has some dependency on another class; however, the
   latter class has incompatibly changed after the compilation of the
-  former class."<sup>[1](#myfootnote1)</sup> The reference can be
+  former class."<sup>[1](#myfootnote1)</sup> The dependency can be

replies.bodyText: Line 25 is a direct quote from the JDK documentation. We're overloading the term "reference" here to mean something other than what it means everywhere else. That's the confusion.
replies.author: elharo

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
              through a class literal, a field access, or a method invocation.
          
          
            
              symbolic reference to a class literal, a field access, or a method invocation.
timeline.author: suztomo
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -24,7 +24,7 @@ permalink: /glossary
 - **Linkage error**: an abnormal condition of a classpath in which a
   "class has some dependency on another class; however, the
   latter class has incompatibly changed after the compilation of the
-  former class."<sup>[1](#myfootnote1)</sup> The reference can be
+  former class."<sup>[1](#myfootnote1)</sup> The dependency can be
   through a class literal, a field access, or a method invocation.

replies.bodyText: That introduces a new term here that is not defined and not otherwise used on this page.
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText:
@elharo I thought about the difference between "dependency" and "symbolic reference". The symbolic references in the constant pool of class files are the implementation detail of the "dependency" written in the java.lang.LinkageError Javadoc.  Therefore the term "symbolic reference" does not belong to this doc.
Does this match your thought?
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: It's simpler than that. We're quoting here from the official JDK docs, with citation. We use the same term they use. We do not need to introduce new and unfamiliar terms to define a linkage error here.
replies.author: elharo
